results.title: Caroms
results.creator_credit: Crystal Gandrud and International Film Bureau
results.brief_description: Animation is used to exhibit the relationship between a carom an a reflection. This principle is used to solve elementary geometric inequalities, and to explore Fagano’s problem: To find a triangle of minimum perimeter that can be inscribed in a given acute-angled triangle. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Borneo's cathedral of trees
results.creator_credit: Richard Brock and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: David Attenborough goes in search of wildlife in the Borneo jungle, and finds the world’s largest flower; night creatures such as the tarsier, the slow loris, and the pangolin; and the nomadic Puran tribe who hunt for food using deadly blowpipes. Suitable for upper primary and secondary years 7-12.

results.title: Antarctica (Episode 3)
results.brief_description: Looks at the heroic early exploration of the continent and the ensuing exploitation if its wildlife, the flora and fauna, and the scientific studies beng carried out in Antarctica today. The possibility of future utilization of Antarctica’s mineral wealth is discusssed.

results.title: Young fingers on a typewriter: a new concept in learning
results.creator_credit: Grace Petitclerc, Les Thomsen Productions and University of California, Los Angeles
results.brief_description:
Shows how children aged between six to twelve developed their typing skill, at the same time advancing in lateral dominance, self image, spelling, reading and storywriting.
Suitable for tertiary/teacher level.

results.title: Swimming in the primary school
results.creator_credit: Derek Monk and Educational Foundation for Visual Aids
results.brief_description:
This film studies swimming lessons with junior children showing three levels: a class of beginners; a mixed-ability class; and a class in which all the children can swim and are working to make their strokes more efficient and to build up stamina.
Suitable for upper primary level.

results.title: Phillip and the white colt
results.creator_credit: Richard Sarafian, John Danischewsky and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description: A lonely mute boy encounters a wild colt, and attempts to tame it. They become inseparable. The aniimal’s life is threatened and in the suspenseful climax the boy’s love helps to save the colt and restores his own powers of speech. Edited from the 1969 Columbia motion picture entitled ‘Run wild, run free.’

results.title: Cracking the stone age code
results.creator_credit: David Collison, Paul Johnstone and BBC-TV
results.brief_description: Examines the work of Alexander Thom, former professor of engineering science at Oxford, whose investigations into stone circles and standing circles of Britain threaten to upset prehistoric knowledge. We see him at work in Scotland, and then go to Britain to see how his findings apply there.

results.title: Cholesterol: eat your heart out
results.brief_description: Set in Toronto, this film follows an experiment designed to determine the effect of diet on the blood cholesterol level of high school students. Points out benefits of reducing cholesterol in the diet. Suitable for secondary school level.
